journal-meta.journal-title: Recherche et Applications en Marketing (English Edition)

title-group.article-title: The relevance of multifactorial gender and its measure in marketing

author-notes.corresp: Isabelle Ulrich, Assistant Professor, Rouen Business School, Bd André Siegfried F-76825 Mont-Saint-Aignan. Email: iul@rouenbs.fr

abstract.p: This article outlines the relevance of gender, and its measurement, in providing meaningful insights into marketing research. The authors show that gender has evolved towards a multifactorial approach with three main factors: cognitive (with gender identity), affective and behavioral. Gender adds an explanatory dimension to our understanding of consumer behavior beyond biological sex, preferably within a multifactorial approach. The authors also explain when, and how, to apply gender and its measurement, identifying the situations where using gender is relevant, distinguishing between biological, social, cultural and situational contexts.

body.p: Biological gender is a widely used segmentation criterion in marketing, and for a long time it was believed sufficient to explain many types of behavior. For several decades, the roles of men and women were clearly differentiated: men were expected to work away from the home, while women completed their tasks indoors. Men were associated with cigars and drills, women with cosmetics and lingerie. Women were thought to be soft and loving, men strong and courageous. The 20th century turned this convenient order on its head. Women began to work away from the home while men began to do the shopping and look after the children. Biological sex thus became insufficient in some cases to explain behavior.

The notion of gender emerged, that proportion of femininity and masculinity that we all share, beyond the differences between the sexes. Many studies were carried out exploring the appeal of this concept in marketing research. Both men and women buy Christmas presents, for example, women more frequently than their male counterparts. But researchers showed that men who were more involved in such purchases were more feminine than others (Fischer and Arnold, 1990, 1994). The notion of gender gave us a deeper understanding of the behavior of a particular sex, men in this case. Which kind of men should be displayed in advertising for men? Martin and Gnoth (2009) showed that more masculine men preferred typically ‘male’ models, whereas more feminine men will prefer more feminine male models, but only in private, as the opinions of others cause them to conform to gender stereotypes in public. Furthermore, masculine brands are preferred by masculine men, while feminine brands are preferred by the most feminine women (Alreck et al., 1982). This means that gender – that of individuals, products or brands – can provide us with a better understanding of certain types of consumer behavior. But while it is relatively easy to measure biological sex, capturing gender is more complex, with a multitude of measurement tools making it easy to lose track. This raises the question of how to measure gender, which presupposes the question: what is gender?

The purpose of this article is to clarify the concept of gender and to present the current state of research on its measurement, both in terms of social psychology – the main field in which gender measures have been developed – and marketing.1 We will show how the concept of gender has evolved from a one-dimensional to a multifactorial approach. Then, through an analysis of the marketing literature that uses gender measurement, we will see that gender provides an additional explanatory dimension to the notion of sex, primarily when a multifactorial measure is used. Then, we propose a conceptual framework allowing to better take into account multifactorial gender in marketing. Finally, we explore situations in which gender and its measurement can be used, and we suggest future research in terms of methodological questions and themes that may be developed.

sec.title: Towards a multifactorial concept of gender
sec.p: While the concept of gender is now well and truly established in the English-speaking literature, its use in France in consumer behavior research remains marginal. Beginning in 1980, the word gender (genre in French) began to be used in the French language, but the term has only really been taken up in the French academic world since the 1990s (Hurtig et al., 1991). Gender is often used in many disciplines – sociology, psychology, political science, human resources management and marketing – but is often approached by researchers in an ambiguous way. A clarification of this concept would appear necessary.

When Simone de Beauvoir wrote in 1949 that ‘one is not born, but rather becomes, a woman’, many social scientists began to question the essence of masculine and feminine identity, demonstrating that the fact of being male or female carried a cultural dimension. The roles attributed to the two sexes, as well as masculine/feminine personality traits, vary from one civilization to the next, although all civilizations tend to assign them distinct social roles (Godelier, 1982; Lévi-Strauss, 1979; Mead, 1963[1928], 1966[1948]). However, the early authors spoke of the cultural dimension of sex, of masculine–feminine but not yet of gender. The term ‘gender’ was applied for the first time to individuals in an academic context by Stoller (1968), who distinguished sex from gender in his work on transsexuality in order to separate biological sex from the identification of the self as a man or woman. But the first definition can be traced back to the sociologist Oakley (1972): ‘“Sex” is a word that refers to the biological differences between male and female […] “Gender” however is a matter of culture: it refers to the social classification into “masculine” and “feminine”.’ More than sex, therefore, gender allows us to understand the social and cultural distinction between masculine and feminine. Sex is biological, gender is a ‘social sex’. It accounts for all of the psychological and sociocultural influences at work in a given civilization and which shape our understanding of masculine/feminine and the roles assigned to men and women. It is rooted in a particular culture at a particular moment in time and ‘refers to the constellation of characteristics and behaviors which come to be differentially associated with and expected of men and women in a particular society, our notions of masculinity and femininity’ (Burr, 1988: 11). This is the definition that we will be using in this article.

While the determination of an individual’s (biological) sex appears straightforward,2 it is more complex to determine his/her (social) gender. Not all studies on gender necessarily use measures; some adopt qualitative perspectives. This approach is well represented in the conferences on gender that have been organized by the Association for Consumer Research since 1991 and in various academic papers (Costa, 1994; Stern, 1993; Thompson, 1996). However, the purpose of this article is to understand the appeal of gender rather than sex as a measured explanatory factor, so we will therefore be concentrating on research that uses gender and gender measurement, overlooking any qualitative and interpretive approaches.

sec.title: Gender and gender measurement
sec.p: While authors agree that gender is a social construct (Bereni et al., 2008), the application of this concept to measurement scales often reveals different understandings of gender. Although in theory it is necessary to clearly define concepts before creating measurement tools, an analysis of the social psychology literature shows that gender measures have often been developed on an imprecise conceptual basis. In some cases, the theoretical work even took place after the creation of such measurements, which were actually used to enrich the theory. This is why this section outlines together the main conceptual approaches to gender and their transfer to measurement, showing how authors have evolved from a unidimensional and later bidimensional conceptualization to a multifactorial approach.

sec.title: A unidimensional conceptualization of gender
sec.p: In early psychology studies, gender only appears through the concepts of masculinity and femininity, which were seen as a set of personality traits, some of which were exclusively associated with men and others exclusively with women; no one could possess both at once. This meant that masculinity and femininity were conceptualized as two opposite poles of a single continuum (Terman and Miles, 1936). This conceptualization can be seen in more global measurements of personality such as the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) (Hathaway and McKinley, 1943) or Gough’s California Psychological Inventory (CPI) (1956).

sec.title: A bidimensional approach to gender
sec.p: The unidimensional approach opposing masculinity to femininity was challenged by Constantinople (1973) and Bem (1974), who argued that ‘psychologically healthy’ men and women possess both masculine and feminine traits. Bem developed a measurement tool – the Bem Sex Role Inventory (BSRI) (1974) – and showed that some individuals report themselves as having high feminine and masculine traits (androgynous), while others see themselves as only very masculine or very feminine.3 Beyond one’s biological sex, it was argued that each individual had a sex role identity4 or gender identity that could be defined by the extent to which they identify with characteristically masculine/feminine personality traits in western societies. This approach assimilated gender to gender identity and understood it according to two distinct and orthogonal dimensions: masculinity and femininity (Figure 1).

In the same year, Spence et al. (1974) reached the same conclusions and presented their measurement tool, the Personal Attribute Questionnaire (PAQ), followed in 1978 with a shorter version, which is used more often (Hoffman, 2001). However, this instrument did not claim to capture gender as a whole but simply to measure two dimensions of it: instrumentality, associated with the masculine, and expressivity, associated with the feminine (Spence et al., 1978), in reference to the theories of Parsons and Bales (1955) and Bakan (1966).5 Yet Bem’s (1974) approach became the most popular within the scientific community (Palan, 2001), despite criticisms of its conceptual shortcomings (Pedhazur and Tetenbaum, 1979; Spence et al., 1978) and its imperfect scales (Orlofsky et al., 1977; Spence et al., 1975).

In response to these criticisms, Bem (1981a) provided a post-hoc explanation of her theory on gender identity: ‘gender schema’ theory, akin to self-schemas. Individuals classified as masculine or feminine are gender-schematic: they are thought to have internalized the roles/psychological traits associated with men and women and to use gender as an organizing and encoding principle to process information about them or the world around them. Inversely, gender-aschematic individuals such as androgynous and undifferentiated are not thought to use gender as an organizing principle. All of the behavior and attitudes of individuals are therefore coherent with their gender identity.6 Bem (1981b) also developed a shorter version of the BSRI, which became the reference measurement tool for gender research (Beere, 1990).

However, many papers were written criticizing this conceptualization and the BSRI, and gender schema theory was challenged (Ashmore, 1990; Spence, 1993). It was argued that gender identity could not be perceived as a global concept of masculinity/femininity or gender (Deaux, 1985; Spence and Helmreich, 1980), but only as one dimension of gender (Spence, 1993). As for the BSRI, critics denounced the way the traits were selected (Ashmore, 1990; Lewin, 1984), the methodology used to classify individuals (Markus et al., 1982; Marsh and Myers, 1986), problems relating to the validity of scores (Myers and Gonda, 1982; Spence, 1984), and the unreliability of the longer version (Lippa, 1985): only the shorter version was considered worth using (Hoffman, 2001). Finally, the BSRI was harshly criticized for its inclusion of the adjectives ‘masculine’ and ‘feminine’ at the same level as the personality traits that supposedly described masculinity/femininity such as ‘independent’ or ‘gentle’ (Hoffman, 2001; Spence and Buckner, 2000). The PAQ had a more modest ambition, as it did not measure gender but only instrumental and expressive traits.

sec.title: Multifactorial gender
sec.p: Most authors now seem to agree to conceptualize gender as a combination of factors (Ashmore, 1990; Aube et al., 1995; Signorella and Frieze, 2008; Spence and Buckner, 2000; Tobin et al., 2010; Twenge, 1999). Multifactorial gender was first developed by Spence and her co-authors, for whom gender is a ‘combination of independent factors that have various degrees and kinds of associations with one another at any given development stage, and interact in complex ways to determine behavior, depending on the context’ (Spence, 1984, 1993; Spence and Buckner, 2000; Spence and Helmreich, 1980). According to Spence and Sawin (1985), multifactorial gender includes five factors:7

list-item.p: An individual’s sense of belonging to the masculine or feminine gender: this can be measured by the adjectives ‘masculine’ and ‘feminine’ (Spence, 1993).8

Instrumental/expressive personality traits (or gender identity): individuals evaluate themselves using descriptive adjectives such as ‘competitive’, ‘determined’ or ‘never give up’ for instrumental/masculine traits, and ‘tender’, ‘understanding’ or ‘emotional’ for expressive/feminine traits. These qualities can be measured using the instrumentality/expressivity scales of the PAQ (1978), masculinity/femininity scales of the shorter version of the BSRI (1981), or the M/F dimensions of the Occupations, Activities and Traits (OAT) scale (Liben and Bigler, 2002).

Gender-role attitudes: individual attitudes towards the rules, rights and responsibilities of men and women (Fischer and Arnold, 1994), often referred to simply as ‘gender attitudes’. Individuals may be categorized as having traditional or modern attitudes towards gender, depending on the extent to which they agree with items such as ‘sons in a family should be given more encouragement to go to college than daughters’ or ‘telling dirty jokes should be mostly a masculine prerogative’ (taken from the Attitudes towards Women Scale (AWS) (Spence and Helmreich, 1972)). This scale has dominated the literature, followed by the Gender Attitudes Inventory (GAI) (Ashmore et al., 1995). The OAT (Liben and Bigler, 2002) is also designed to measure attitudes towards (1) stereotypical masculine/feminine traits, and (2) masculine/feminine occupations and activities.9

Sex-role behavior, gendered occupations and interests: these are the sex-specific forms of behavior and roles adopted by each individual, as well as pastimes, professions and activities, some of which are considered typically feminine (e.g. florist or babysitter) and others typically masculine (e.g. astronomer or plumber). Three main measurement tools are used: the Male–Female Relations Questionnaire (MFRQ) (Spence et al., 1978), which only evaluates gender-related behavior, and especially the Sex Role Behavior Scale (SRBS) (Orlofksy and O’Heron, 1987) or OAT, developed more recently.

Sexual orientation, which is usually measured by self-classification (heterosexual/homosexual/bisexual) or using the scale devised by Klein et al. (1985), which allows respondents to situate themselves on a continuum between completely homosexual and completely heterosexual.

sec.p: Research has shown that there is limited correlation between these factors (Aube and Koestner, 1995; Orlosky and O’Heron, 1987; Spence and Buckner, 2000): an individual may have expressive/feminine traits but not display traditional attitudes towards gender or have feminine interests.

Some scholars complement these five gender factors with individual gendered physical attributes (Ashmore, 1990; Deaux, 1985),10 gender centrality – the importance one attaches to gender as a component of self-concept (Luhtanen and Crocker, 1992) – and gender self-confidence, i.e. the intensity with which individuals believe they satisfy their personal standards in terms of gender (Hoffman et al., 2000). Finally, Egan and Perry (2001) introduced gender typicality (the perceived degree of similarity with one’s sex group), gender contentedness (satisfaction with one’s gender) and felt pressure for gender conformity (perceived pressure from self and others to adhere to gender stereotypes).

Table 1 provides a review of the various gender factors and the corresponding measures with their psychometric qualities, in psychology and social psychology since 1995.11 It reveals that the main factors used are: (1) gender identity; ( 2) attitudes towards gender; and (3) gendered behavior, occupations and interests. Most studies that evaluate gender identity using the PAQ (19 out of 33) adopt a multifactorial approach and measure other gender factors, as do all of the studies that use the OAT (4 studies). However, all of the studies that assess gender identity with the BSRI (13 studies) adopt the approach from Bem (1981a), without measuring other gender factors. Overall, one third of studies (26 out of 74) measure several gender factors, with the most recent articles favoring multiple measurements. The remaining two thirds (48 out of 74), due to the issue being studied in the research, evaluate only one factor: gender identity (27 studies), attitudes towards gender (17 studies) or, more rarely, gendered behavior and interests (4 studies). Sexual orientation is primarily measured in studies looking at the homosexual population, with no attention paid to other gender factors (except in the case of Blashill and Powlishta, 2009). We are seeing the development of studies that use the OAT (2002) to evaluate both gender identity and gendered behavior, occupations and interests. Finally, gender typicality, gender contentedness and felt pressure for gender conformity have been used in recent studies, demonstrating the potential of these new factors in gender research (Tobin et al., 2010).

caption.p: Main gender factors evaluated in the field of social psychology since 1995, together with corresponding measure and articles.

sec.p: However, the literature does not specify which gender factors should be used according to the context of the research. Spence (1993) suggests one should select the factors that seem conceptually relevant to the phenomenon being studied, and in particular that one should use gender identity only in situations referring to the instrumentality/expressiveness of individuals.

We have shown, therefore, that behind the differences in measurements one finds different conceptualizations of gender. Whereas early studies saw gender as being unidimensional, this perspective was later abandoned for a multifactorial approach, which is now currently adopted by most psychology researchers. Yet this multifactorial perspective is very rarely considered by marketing scholars, as we will see in the next section.

sec.title: Gender in marketing: Contributions of this concept and its measurement
sec.p: This section offers a review of marketing studies operationalizing gender and its measure, in an effort to analyze the gender factors that have been used and the impact they have on the research variables outlined, following on from the work of Palan (2001). While the influence of human gender on consumption is often studied in the marketing literature, researchers have also shown the relevance of the notion of gender for product categories and brands, thereby capturing it through specific measurement. We will begin by reviewing the studies that have measured the effect of gender on consumer behavior and on communication, before moving on to those that try to link the gender of individuals to the gender of products or brands. This analysis will show that earlier studies used unidimensional gender measures, while more recent research has evolved towards a multifactorial approach, allowing for a more refined understanding of the phenomena being studied.

sec.title: The influence of consumer gender on consumer behavior
sec.p: Most studies concluded that the gender of individuals is an explanatory factor for their behavior (see Table 2). Seven studies are conceptualized with the bidimensional approach, only measuring gender identity (in most cases using the BSRI). Six of them suggest that gender has a significant effect on behavior: they analyze several situations likely to activate the instrumental (masculine) and expressive (feminine) traits of an individual’s gender identity, following the recommendations of Spence (1993). Thus Gainer (1993) shows the positive effect of expressive (feminine) traits on the level of one’s involvement in art and the practice of the arts, a domain of expressivity. Winterich et al. (2009) demonstrate the impact of gender identity on the capacity of individuals to make donations to in-groups or out-groups:14 here it was relevant to use gender identity as donation draws on the expressive and instrumental traits of the individual. By contrast, Kahle and Homer (1985) show that sex is more influential than gender identity: but these authors studied preferences in terms of food, using dishes that did not particularly solicit the expressiveness or instrumentality of consumers: measuring gender identity there makes no sense.

caption.p: Influence of individual gender on consumer behavior.

tr.td: Studies using bidimensional conceptualization of gender without gender influence
Sex but not masculine/feminine traits have an influence on food preferences.
Studies using bidimensional conceptualization of gender, showing gender influence
Instrumental women have more influence on the purchasing decisions made by couples than expressive women.
Positive effect of masculine/feminine gender of the woman on her influence within the family unit.
Sex has a greater predictive capacity than gender in terms of attitudes and behavior towards fashion. However, gender explains differences within a particular sex.
The feminine traits of men increase (and masculine traits decrease) when purchasing a gift for a woman but not for a man. No significant difference in the case of women.

Feminine/expressive gender has an indirect effect on the practice of the arts in terms of involvement. It has a direct effect on involvement in the arts, whereas sex has no more than an indirect effect.

For individuals with feminine traits, the more they claim a strong moral identity, the more they make donations to out-groups (Iraqis and Indonesians). In the case of individuals with masculine traits, the more they claim a strong moral identity, the more they make donations to in-groups (London and New Orleans residents).
Studies with multifactorial conceptualization of gender, showing gender influence

Masculine/feminine traits are associated with performance expectations with regard to women who manage an activity. Gender attitudes are associated with performance expectations with regard to others, regardless of sex.

Men and women with feminine traits are more involved in the purchase of Christmas gifts than those with masculine traits. Gender attitudes have an impact on the level of involvement in such purchases.

Individual gender (masculine/feminine traits) has a greater explanatory value than sex in the case of Christmas gift purchases. Gender attitudes have an even greater influence than masculine/feminine traits.

Highly instrumental men remember their gift purchasing experiences more than highly expressive men. Expressive men/women have memories associated with people, while instrumental men/women have memories associated with objects.
Studies looking at sexual orientation and showing gender influence
Sexual orientation has an effect on one’s dependence on clothes shopping: homosexuals are more dependent than heterosexuals, and young people more than older people.
Sexual orientation has an effect on online shopping: homosexuals and bisexuals purchase more than others.
Homosexual men are more innovative than heterosexuals. The reverse is true of lesbian women.

sec.p: Four other studies adopted a multifactorial approach to gender, showing that gender had a greater impact than sex. They looked at attitudes towards gender as well as gender identity, or explicitly referred to the multifactorial approach (Palan et al., 2001). According to Fischer and Arnold (1994), gender attitudes have a greater influence than gender identity on gift-giving, demonstrating the pertinence of including this factor in research. The different contexts of these four studies were relevant for the use of gender identity: performance expectations among senior managers in the case of Martin and Roberts (1983) or gift-exchange behaviors (Fischer and Arnold, 1990, 1994; Palan et al., 2001), in other words situations in which the instrumentality or expressiveness of individuals may be expressed. Finally, sexual orientation has a significant influence in relevant contexts such as clothing consumption.

So gender significantly impacts consumer behavior. Yet when it is evaluated using gender identity, it is essential that the two dimensions instrumentality/expressiveness are relevant to the problem being studied. Gender identity is the most measured factor; however, the most recent studies, which favor a multifactorial approach, demonstrate the pertinence of using gender attitudes and sexual orientation to shed light on behavior.

sec.title: The influence of consumer’s gender on communication
sec.p: Most publications show the impact of gender (Table 3), by adopting a bidimensional approach and measuring gender identity with the short version of the BSRI, which received less criticism than its longer counterpart (Hoffman, 2001). These specific studies also analyze situations raising gender stereotypes and the instrumentality/expressiveness of individuals: measuring gender identity is meaningful here. Four studies relate to advertisements in which women are presented in traditional or egalitarian sexual roles. Similarly, recent research by Feiereisen et al. (2009) and Martin and Gnoth (2009) display situations in which the gender identity of the advertising models varies (more or less ‘feminine’ women and more or less ‘masculine’ men). In conditions where gender stereotypes are salient and active, gender identity can help explain attitudes towards advertising and preferences for the models used.

caption.p: Influence of individual gender on communications.

tr.td: Studies with bidimensional conceptualization of gender without gender influence
Biological sex appears to have a greater explanatory value than M/F traits when it comes to remembering advertising. However, differences can be identified within each sex, associated with gender.

Attitudes towards advertising for jeans (with a man or woman adopting a posture that does or does not conform to their gender role) differ according to sex but not according to gender. Tests carried out on 18 M/F magazines showed that differences in memorization, choice and response time vary according to biological sex but not according to gender.
Studies showing gender influence (bidimensional or multifactorial conceptualization)

M/instrumental traits have a greater explanatory value than sex for purchasing intentions. Congruence between subjects with traditional gender attitudes and their appreciation of advertising with a traditional female model (and congruence between egalitarian attitudes and appreciation of advertising with a non-conformist female model).
M/F traits significantly associated with preferences for advertising showing more or less traditional feminine roles. This relationship differs according to product category.
Modern female models in advertising have a positive effect on purchase intent in the case of financial services. Instrumental women prefer advertising with a modern female model.

Exposure to press advertising creates greater confidence with regard to general information in the case of subjects with marked instrumental traits (masculine and androgynous) than in the case of other subjects.

The congruence between the gender identity of women and the gender identity of female models in adverts has a positive influence on attitudes towards those adverts. Involvement in advertising is a mediating variable in this relationship.
Masculine/instrumental men prefer typically masculine models. ‘Feminine’ men privately prefer more feminine male models, although in public say they prefer more masculine models.
Studies looking at sexual orientation with gender influence
Media practices differ according to sexual orientation. More negative attitudes towards advertising among homosexuals than heterosexuals.

The unfavorable effects of targeted advertising are more marked among non-distinctive groups (whites, heterosexuals), while the favorable effects of targeted advertising are more marked among distinctive groups (Africans, homosexuals).
Homosexual men and women have a more positive attitude towards gay-friendly brands than heterosexuals, although the latter do not have a negative attitude towards such brands.
Consumer attitudes to advertising with homosexual or heterosexual content differ according to the sexual orientation and sex of individuals.

sec.p: Just one study (Coughlin and O’Connor, 1985) looked at gender from a multifactorial perspective, demonstrating the effect of gender attitudes towards advertising, beyond the impact of gender identity. Furthermore, studies analyzing sexual orientation conclude that it is influential in situations where individuals’ beliefs and perceptions with regard to homosexuality/heterosexuality are mobilized. By contrast, studies that conclude that gender has no impact apply a bidimensional conceptualization to gender and analyze contexts that are not well adapted to the use of gender identity assessing instrumentality/expressiveness – as in the case of advertising recall (Gentry and Haley, 1984; Schmitt et al., 1988) – or use the longer version of the BSRI, whose shortcomings have been highlighted by the literature.

Thus gender appears as a good predictor to better understand consumer behavior towards advertising when the context is relevant: because advertising displays incongruous or stereotypical masculine/feminine roles and because the models used are typically masculine or feminine, etc. Gender identity is the factor most used, although the multifactorial approach seems promising: gender attitudes are a factor that can shed further light, and sexual orientation is worth using in specific contexts. These findings corroborate those put forward in the previous section.

sec.title: Studies that link consumer gender to the gender of products or brands
sec.p: Focusing on consumer gender has led researchers to examine its links with the gender of products and brands. By applying the notion of gender to these marketing objects, they sought to measure it, first by transposing the tools used on individuals, and then by developing specific instruments where possible. The initial studies carried out in this field sought to explain the purchasing behavior of men and women through the gender of the products purchased: some products were seen to be feminine, such as make-up, and others masculine, such as whisky. Then, much more recently, gender has been used in relation to brands by researchers who examine the influence of gender on the way consumers evaluate masculine/feminine brands or brand extensions. These papers contribute to our understanding of gender measurement, demonstrating parallels with the measure of human gender, often by using an anthropocentric approach. Furthermore, more recent research also tends towards a multifactorial approach. We will begin by presenting those studies that measure the gender of products, followed by those that look at gender transposed onto brands, and finally those that examine the potential link between the gender of consumers and the gender of products/brands.

sec.title: Measuring the gender of products: a bidimensional approach
sec.p: Just as some researchers suggest that brands have a personality, others posit that products have a gender. The male versus female categorization is one of the first classification systems learned by children in our cultures (Powlishta et al., 2001), a process that is internalized to such an extent that adults use it without being fully aware they are doing so (Schneider, 2004). Products and brands do not escape the system: they are also thought to be perceived through the prism of gender. For example, hairsprays and deodorants are perceived to be feminine, while cigarettes and cigars are seen as masculine (Morris and Cundiff, 1971; Stuteville, 1971). Many objects carry sex-specific connotations for individuals: depending on their shape, size or color, they are seen to be either masculine or feminine (Damak, 1996; Kirkham, 1996; Sohier, 2004; Tissier-Desbordes and Kimmel, 2002). The gender of a product would appear to be linked to the biological gender of its stereotypical user (Allison et al., 1980).

In early studies, the gender of products was measured using a bipolar unidimensional approach, and later using a bidimensional approach with two distinct constructs – masculinity and femininity (Allison et al., 1980; Milner and Fodness, 1996) – with more recent work confirming this perception of product gender (Fugate and Phillips, 2010). But what of brands?

sec.title: Transposing gender onto brands: the shift towards multifactorial gender
sec.p: The perception of brand gender is indirectly tackled by the literature in terms of brand personality. Levy (1959) includes characteristics such as human personality, age, social class and gender; Aaker (1997) uses ‘masculine’ and ‘feminine’ traits in her brand personality scale. Most other measures of brand personality include items taken from scales measuring human gender (Ambroise, 2006: Caprara et al., 2001; Ferrandi and Valette-Florence, 2002). In these papers, gender appears to be an underlying feature of brand personality but does not exist outright. Yet several authors have highlighted the masculine or feminine dimension of brands (Fournier, 1998; Keller, 1993; McCracken, 1989). This sexualized image appears to be based on the consumer associated with the brand (Keller, 1993). However, very few studies directly deal with brand gender or attempt to measure it (see Table 4). The most recent studies use the notion of brand gender in situations where brands originally masculine or feminine are extended to target the opposite sex.15 Jung and Lee (2006) argue that brand gender has an influence on the way in which such brand extensions are evaluated: feminine brands that are extended to the male target are less appreciated than the reverse. Veg (2009) shows that such evaluations are more favorable when the parent brand is perceived to be ‘gender open’ rather than ‘gender closed’.16

tr.td: Congruence between the masculinity/femininity of smokers and their preference for masculine or feminine cigarettes.
More feminine men prefer more feminine cigarette brands. More feminine women prefer more feminine brands.

Effect of gender on preferences for masculine or feminine beer or jeans brands.
Conditioning advertising displaying masculine or feminine images results in a perception of brand gender independently of attitudes towards the brand.
Effect of brand gender on the evaluation of brand extensions into the opposite sex. Sex also has an effect.

Brand spokespersons have an influence on perceptions of the brand’s masculine or feminine personality. The congruence between a brand’s masculine or feminine personality and the consumer’s gender identity has a positive influence on their attitudes towards the brand.
Multidimensional(masculinity and femininity scales with three dimensions: (1) associated user sex; (2) gendered attributes of products; (3) gendered personality traits of brand)
Brand masculinity and femininity: two separate constructs. The more a brand is feminine (masculine), the less its extension to the masculine (feminine) is appreciated.

sec.p: However, most of these studies offer a unidimensional (masculine versus feminine) conceptualization of brand gender (Alreck et al., 1982; Fry, 1971; Jung and Lee, 2006; Till and Priluck, 2001; Vitz and Johnston, 1965; Worth et al., 1992). This is not coherent with the bidimensional conceptualization of product gender previously outlined. Conversely, Debevec and Iyer (1986) adopted a two-dimensional approach to brand gender in order to show the impact of the sex of the advertising spokesperson on brand gender. Grohmann (2009) recently developed a measurement scale of gendered brand personality using two constructs (masculine/feminine brand personality). She suggests that brands can be divided into four groups, reproducing the gender approach adopted by Bem (1974): (1) highly masculine/low feminine; (2) low masculine/highly feminine; (3) low masculine and feminine; and (4) highly feminine and masculine. Finally, Ulrich et al. (2010) suggest six components of brand gender for consumers: (1) the gender of the main brand user; (2) the brand’s masculine/feminine personality traits; (3) the gendered attributes of the brand communication; (4) the gender of the brand name; (5) the gendered attributes of the brand logo; and (6) the gendered attributes and benefits of the products. They added several gender factors including the name, following on from Yorkston and De Mello (2005), who showed that in Spanish (a formal language system, like French) consumers have a more favorable view of brands with the masculine or feminine name that corresponds to the sex of the product’s typical user.20 This suggests that just as the gender of individuals is a multifactorial concept, so too is the gender of brands.

sec.title: Links between consumer gender and the gender of products or brands
sec.p: Earlier studies demonstrated that the gender of individuals impacts their evaluation of masculine/feminine products by using a unidimensional gender measure (Table 5). This implies that feminine traits explain attitudes towards decoration and clothing products, which are seen as feminine (Aiken, 1963). More masculine men prefer more masculine cigarette brands, while more feminine men opt for more feminine brands and more feminine women prefer more feminine cigarette brands (Fry, 1971; Vitz and Johnston, 1965).

caption.p: Link between consumer gender and product/brand gender.

sec.p: Most studies produced disappointing findings by using Bem’s bidimensional gender measure (1974), which has since been refuted, and by measuring only gender identity. However, these studies (Gentry and Doering, 1977, 1979; Gentry et al., 1978) used the PAQ with no consideration for the relevance of context: they did not particularly target the instrumentality/expressiveness of individuals. Other studies conceptually based on gender identity are operationalized using the long version of the BSRI, a measure whose shortcomings we have already highlighted (Golden and Allison, 1979; Allison et al., 1980; Schmitt et al., 1988).

By contrast, the four most recent studies to conclude that the gender of individuals has an impact used a multifactorial approach, particularly measuring gender attitudes. Furthermore, these studies analyzed situations in which gender stereotypes are apparent, such as experiments involving highly masculine/feminine brands (Alreck et al., 1982; Sorin Ulrich, 2010; Worth et al., 1992), whereby the gender of consumers explains their brand preferences.

This analysis shows gender to have an influence and an additional explanatory value over sex in many marketing studies, but it should ideally satisfy two conditions: multifactorial conceptualization and relevant context. The most frequently used gender factors have been gender identity, followed by gender attitudes and sexual orientation in some studies. Gender identity offers an explanation for many forms of consumer behavior; however, it essentially evaluates instrumentality and expressiveness. Researchers must therefore consider the relevance of these two dimensions in the context being studied, and must not confuse expressiveness/femininity with instrumentality/masculinity. Gender attitudes are usually of a greater explanatory value than gender identity in the study of consumer behavior and preferences for masculine/feminine brands. Sex-role behavior and gendered occupations and interests are factors that are absent from marketing research, although their relevance has been demonstrated in psychology studies. This marketing literature review has also highlighted the value of applying the notion of gender to products and brands and of measuring the gender of brands using a multifactorial approach. The following section tries to pinpoint the situations in marketing in which gender should be used as a complement or instead of biological sex, and the gender factors to be taken into account.

sec.title: When and how should gender be used in marketing?
sec.p: Gender can provide us with a better understanding of consumer behavior, but only if appropriate measurement tools are used – preferably as part of a multifactorial approach, and exclusively in relevant situations.

sec.title: Gender salience
sec.p: The concept of gender does not make sense in all research contexts. Biological sex continues to be a satisfactory variable in many cases: it is a single segmentation variable that is easily identifiable and accessible (Putrevu, 2004). However, we have shown that gender can have more influence and be of greater explanatory value than sex in understanding consumer behavior in certain situations. While researchers agree on the contextual aspect of gender, very few papers specify the relevant contexts in which to use it. In a situation in which elements of the self-concept relating to gender are activated, beliefs and behavior can be influenced by gender: this is referred to as gender salience, just as one speaks of the salient features of a product. Deaux and Major (1987) have suggested that individual gender may be activated in four types of situation: (1) if aspects of the context make gender salient (e.g. an incongruous situation in terms of gendered roles); (2) if the actions of another person towards the individual result in gender salience (e.g. seduction context); (3) if the individual’s self-concept in terms of gender is frequently or has just been invoked (e.g. the individual is the minority member in a group of the opposite sex); and (4) if that individual feels that gender is a central component of self-concept. The feminine dimension of an individual may therefore be more pronounced in a domestic context than in a professional or academic context (Maclaran et al., 2009). Let us take the example of cinema consumption. Gender may not be salient as an explanation for visitor numbers, but in studying film categories such as romantic or war films, the use of gender might make sense, as the consumption of such films may activate the viewer’s identification with a particular gender or his/her gender attitudes.
We suggest that situations of gender salience can be associated with four major contextual categories:

From birth, we are assigned a particular sex by our bodies, thereby influencing our gender. Being a man or a woman has an influence on our masculinity/femininity. As soon as the context or object of analysis is subjected to the influence of the body or biological factors, gender may complement sex by providing additional clarity. For example, if the context relates to products, brands or experiences that are closely linked to a particular sex (e.g. razors or condoms for men, bras or sanitary towels for women), the use of gender may provide an explanation for consumer behavior (in the context of condoms, see Pleck et al., 1993).

The use of gender as a social construct makes sense where social stereotypes about men and women, masculine/feminine roles and the way they are attributed are addressed in the context of the study. Doing the laundry is a task traditionally attributed to women, a stereotype that continues to apply.22 By taking gender into account alongside biological sex, we can better understand the way in which stereotypes are perpetuated. Situations involving purchases or gift-exchanges (Palan et al., 2001), donations (Winterich et al., 2009), or instances of communication that place men and/or women in their masculine/feminine roles (Feiereisen et al., 2009) are examples of relevant social contexts in which gender rather than sex can be used.

Anthropologists have shown that masculinity/femininity varies from one culture to the next. If cultural stereotypes relating to masculinity/femininity are significant in a particular situation, gender can be used as a complement to sex in an effort to better explain behavior (Kimmel et al., 2005). Perceptions of femininity in terms of clothing are different in the West and in Muslim countries (Sandikci and Ger, 2007). Hofstede (2001) suggested that gender is a component of culture, and that some countries are more feminine, such as Thailand, Sweden or Norway, and others more masculine, such as the USA.

Koestner and Aube (1995), in their analysis of the discourse of Anita Roeddick,23 showed it to contain very masculine elements – her role and management methods – but also very feminine ones. Depending on the circumstances or her interlocutors, Roeddick emphasizes her feminine or masculine side. This reveals the contextual nature of gender: every consumer situation that brings out particularly acute stereotypes of masculinity/femininity in relation to a ‘usual’ context can be analyzed with more precision if gender is used as a complement to biological sex.
These four categories are presented in Figure 2, which provides an overview of multifactorial gender as is further explained in the next section.

caption.p: Three components of multifactorial gender and four types of contextual influence.

sec.title: In favor of multifactorial gender
sec.p: While a multifactorial conceptualization of gender appears to be the most appropriate, the many different gender factors and gender measures may be unsettling for researchers. We have categorized the various gender factors in Figure 2, drawing inspiration from Martinot’s self-concept schema (1995)24 and its three components: cognitive, affective and behavioral. The first cube represents the cognitive aspects of gender, with the factors ‘gender identity’ and ‘gender attitudes’, as the items in these measurement scales are of a more cognitive nature.25 The second cube represents the affective aspects of gender, which emerged more recently in the literature: ‘gender contentedness’ (one’s sense of satisfaction at being assigned a particular gender), ‘felt pressure for gender conformity’ (perceived pressure from peers or family members to adhere to gender stereotypes) and ‘gender self-confidence’ (the extent to which one accepts one’s gender). These are clearly three factors, which belong to the affective domain, given the way in which they have been defined by social psychology researchers. The third cube includes the behavioral aspects of gender: gendered occupations and interests or physical appearance. This schema shows the richness of gender conceptualization beyond mere gender identity, although this is the concept most used in marketing studies.

Should all gender factors be measured? First, one must select those whose measure appears relevant to the phenomenon being studied (Spence, 1993). On the basis of the four contextual categories described above, researchers should identify those contextual elements that present stereotypes in terms of gender or masculine/feminine roles and justify questions about their belonging to one of these categories, and then choose the relevant gender factors to answer the research question.

The three components of the cube we propose allow researchers to consider which factors should be included in their study. Cognitive aspects are central, including gender identity and gender attitudes. The former, which is the factor most often operationalized in marketing, is relevant where the instrumentality/expressiveness of consumers is pertinent in the context of the study. Researchers may then use the short version of the BSRI, the measure most frequently used.26 However, as we have already explained, the BSRI raises some issues in terms of score validity and also includes the terms masculine/feminine within the personality traits associated with these two worlds. We therefore feel it is preferable to use the PAQ (1975) to measure expressiveness/instrumentality, or the OAT (2002).27 Apart from its satisfactory psychometric qualities, the OAT includes personality traits that are perceived as masculine/feminine today rather than in the 1970s, when the BSRI was first created.

Furthermore, while gender identity is often used, it should be complemented by the measurement of a second cognitive factor such as gender attitudes, which has a greater predictive capacity and allows for a better understanding of consumer behavior than gender identity in many cases. Several scales, such as the AWS, GAI or OAT (attitude measurement format) can then be used by researchers. By also including a behavioral dimension, the OAT becomes a highly relevant measurement tool in contexts where the influence of masculine/feminine activities and occupations is worth studying.

sec.title: Exploring promising gender research fields
sec.p: Two major categories of future research can be identified: methodological and thematic research.

sec.title: Methodological research
sec.p: Although the cognitive aspects of multifactorial gender have been widely explored by researchers, greater attention is needed on the affective aspects. To what extent can satisfaction with one’s gender have an influence on certain types of consumer behavior? The affective factors of gender proposed by Egan and Perry (2001) – gender contentedness and pressure for gender conformity – could be used in marketing to shed further light on consumer reactions in situations of gender salience. The behavioral dimension of gender also requires further exploration. To what extent do sex-role behavior and gendered occupations and interests play a role in specific types of consumer behavior? For example, do they have an influence on preferences for masculine/feminine brands or on types of communication? This would make it possible to better target consumers according to their gendered occupations and interests.

The complexity and high number of gender factors have led some authors to reject a measurement approach and instead study gender with qualitative methodologies. The study of gender representation in advertising has led some researchers to use qualitative methodology (Caterall and Maclaran, 2002): gender is no longer considered a priori using scales, but rather interpreted a posteriori. Drawing on theories of deconstruction, these researchers reject binary oppositions (male/female, nature/culture) that imply a certain hierarchy. Furthermore, implicit association tests can constitute one methodological option for studying gender, allowing for a reduction in declarative bias (Nosek et al., 2002). Varying methodology in studying gender therefore appears to be a promising research approach.

sec.title: Thematic research
sec.p: There are several thematic research fields that appear to be insufficiently addressed by the literature and could be better understood using multifactorial gender. These can be classified using the contextual categories defined earlier: biological, social, cultural and situational.

Some products are intended for one sex only because of their specific biological features (bras for women, condoms for men). This makes them highly charged in terms of gender. The use of gender theories and various gender factors can provide us with a better understanding of how they are consumed. Pleck et al. (1993) showed that teenagers with traditional attitudes towards masculinity use fewer condoms. One might think that brands that propose highly feminine products such as bras would have more difficulty selling products intended for men under the same brand name. Aubade, a well-known lingerie brand, failed in its attempt to diversify into masculine underwear. A multifactorial approach to gender would allow us to better understand the factors that influence consumers’ acceptance of such extensions, which constitute a major managerial challenge for companies.

By exploring gender issues of various biological age groups, we can shed additional light on certain types of consumer behavior. Childhood is a period in which gender is constructed, but also in which gender stereotypes are very marked (blue for boys and pink for girls, Barbie or GI Joe). Many social psychology studies focus on gender among children and the development of gendered identity (Kohlberg, 1966; Liben and Bigler, 2002; Martin and Halverson, 1981). Yet the marketing literature on children seems to have made little use of gender in order to understand, for example, how toys are chosen. Following several failed attempts to target girls, Lego recently launched Lego Friends for young girls, having carried out five months of tests in an effort to better understand the market: the figures included in this product range represent different types of girls, more or less feminine or masculine (Wieners, 2011). A more masculine girl will most likely not choose the same figures as a very feminine girl, nor is she likely to imagine the same constructions or games.

There are other life stages that are interesting in terms of gender: the arrival of a child, the moment when children leave the home and retirement are all stages when role tasks are re-negotiated (Bauer, 2007). Measuring the influence of multifactorial gender on consumer practices at these key stages would appear to be a promising research field.

list-item.p: 2. Social: Gender, norms and social roles

sec.p: Many consumer situations reflect gender norms and social roles or take place under the gaze of others. We feel it is important to pursue the work of Martin and Gnoth (2009) and Feiereisen et al. (2009), demonstrating the influence of gender on peoples’ reactions to various advertising models (more or less masculine or feminine) in different contexts (in the presence of peers or members of the opposite sex), in an effort to better develop and target advertising communication. Conversely, gender also makes sense where one is not being watched and can lie about one’s sex. It might help shed light on some online practices, given that studies have shown that internet users sometimes lie about their sex and that their interlocutors are often unable to detect the deceit (Herring and Martinson, 2004), except where the discussion relates to a specific subject such as football (Williams and Mendelsohn, 2008).

Furthermore, social norms and gender stereotypes impact our perception of the gender of products and brands. A brand that is primarily consumed by women will be perceived to be feminine. Its extension to the opposite sex will therefore be perceived as challenging, as consumers with traditional gender attitudes will be less favorable to such a move (Sorin Ulrich, 2010). Studies could be carried out using other gender factors in order to help managers better target those segments most likely to accept such developments (Nyeck and Veg, 2007).

It should be pointed out that most marketing studies involving gender have been carried out in the USA. It would appear pertinent to carry out such studies in France, as gender is different in the two cultures (Kimmel and Tissier-Desbordes, 2000). Beyond that, we feel it is appropriate to adopt a resolutely intercultural perspective in any future studies on gender, following on from Feiereisen et al. (2009), Kimmel et al. (2005) and Schertzer et al. (2008).

Research could be carried out in situations associated with a specific gender. Place could itself be associated with a specific gender: a perfume store will be perceived as a more feminine place than a wine store. Gender can be applied to consumer experiences, locations and spaces (Caru et al., 2004). Taking into account the gender of the place can help us to better understand the reluctance among consumers to frequent certain places and thereby better adapt them to their expectations. Following on from the work of Otnes and McGrath (2001) on the purchasing behavior of men in stores, research using multifactorial gender could be carried out to shed light on the reactions of men in a world seen as feminine (perfume stores, hair salons or childcare products) or women in a world seen as masculine (football stadiums, gaming centers or DIY stores).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Gender continues to be a key factor in the way we think and see the world, playing an important symbolic role. Studying gender provides us with a more sophisticated understanding of some behavior types by looking at society and the men and women that form it in a different way. Through a review of the literature on gender measure in social psychology and marketing, this article has shown the relevance of this concept and its measure, but on two conditions: a multifactorial approach must be applied to a situation in which there is gender salience. We have suggested a schema to give an overview of multifactorial gender that categorizes its various factors and includes three main components: the cognitive dimension with gender identity, the affective dimension and the behavioral dimension. We have also suggested a typology for the different contexts of gender salience in order to allow researchers to easily identify those situations in which gender makes sense, and we have recommended scales for each gender dimension. Researchers can therefore draw on these different gender measures according to the issues being addressed and the context of their study. Finally, we suggested future research based on four gender salience contexts. There is a need to continue the study of gender since ‘if gender didn’t exist, what we refer to as sex would be devoid of meaning and would not be perceived as important: it would just be one physical difference among others’ (Delphy, 2001).

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the anonymous readers and editor for the pertinence of their comments and constructive suggestions, which have made a significant contribution in improving this article.

The aim of this article is not to provide an overview of all marketing studies that use the concept of gender but do not measure it. In many current papers from the English-speaking world, the term ‘gender’ replaces the term ‘sex’, often considered to be politically incorrect as it is associated with reproduction and fails to recognize the struggles of feminists, homosexuals and transsexuals. This article does not consider studies that use the word gender instead of sex, whereby gender is reduced to a male/female distinction with no conceptual differentiation from biological sex.

Identifying the ‘true sex’ of an individual is not in fact so straightforward. None of the biological markers of sex (sexual organs, gonads, chromosomes or hormones), when taken individually, provides a clear definition of sex (Fausto-Sterling, 2000). This author estimates that 1.7% of children are born with indeterminate sexual characteristics: modern medicine assigns them a sex on the basis of these biological markers but also their ability to urinate standing up or sitting down or the size of their penis, etc. In France, alongside the genetic identities XX (girl) and XY (boy), it is thought that 60,000 women have three X chromosomes or more, that 60,000 men have an XXY combination, and that there are both XX male and XY female individuals (Vidal et al., 2006).

In 1977, Bem suggested a classification into four categories, adding ‘undifferentiated’ individuals (who report themselves as low on both feminine/masculine traits), following the criticism by Spence et al. (1975). This classification subsequently became the reference for this field of research.

The concept of sex role identity, the term initially used by Bem (1974), is referred to in some papers as sex role or sex role stereotype. Studies carried out after 1980 employ the terms gender identity, gender role identity or gender role identification, as the word sex was considered politically incorrect. We choose the term gender identity, which is more often used in marketing and social psychology.

According to Parsons and Bales (1955), men are characterized by instrumental attributes (e.g. independence or self-confidence) and women by expressive attributes (e.g. tenderness or compassion). According to Bakan (1966), men are dominated by agency traits (e.g. assertive or enterprising) and women by communion traits (e.g. understanding or devoted).
The studies that draw on Bem’s gender schema theory (1981a) use the terms gender identity, gender schema or gender schematization to refer to the same concept.

Some authors refer to multidimensional gender, others to multifactorial gender. We adopt the term multifactorial, which is more widely used and better accounts for the existence of several components or factors within the concept of gender. The term multidimensional may lead to confusion, as some components of gender are themselves multidimensional.

Koestner and Aube (1995) demonstrated that 81% of men and 3% of women see themselves as masculine, whereas 73% of women and 2% of men describe themselves as feminine. Given its proximity to biological sex, this factor is rarely measured.

The OAT is made up of scales that assess Traits (M/F), Occupations (M/F) and Activities (M/F). Each scale can involve a personal measurement or self-evaluation (by measuring M/F traits in this way, you can assess the gender identity factor) or a measure of attitudes (this measurement of M/F traits allows you to assess attitudes towards stereotypically M/F traits and therefore gender-role attitudes).
Aube et al. (1995) showed that male physical attributes are associated with instrumental traits and male behavior/social roles (although no such link was identified for feminine physical attributes).

This date was chosen for three reasons: (1) the last review of gender measurements was done by Beere in 1990; (2) the BSRI continued to be heavily criticized until 1995; and (3) the rise of the multifactorial approach to gender took place after 1995.

We have indicated the Cronbach alphas obtained using these scales in the studies listed. In the case of the MFRQ, which has two scales, we have only mentioned the alphas from the most commonly used scale (social interaction), which exists in both a masculine and feminine version. For the GAI, which is subdivided into three scales and 14 sub-scales, we have provided the lowest and highest values of the alphas obtained. For sexual orientation, most studies use a self-classification measure, meaning there is no calculation for reliability.

There is an abundant literature on sexual orientation (13,466 articles between 1995 and 2011 in psychology databases, although not all of these articles include a measure of the variable). For the purposes of economy, we have only presented the main studies that since 2000 have measured sexual orientation in order to evaluate its influence on the behavior of individuals.
In this study, the in-groups were inhabitants of London or New Orleans, and the out-groups were Iraqis or Indonesians.

Brand extension to the opposite sex is the extension of a product range to the opposite male/female target – Nivea for Men or Gillette Venus for Women. This is an example of a horizontal extension: it involves launching a product in the same category of similar quality and price to the products available in the existing range (Michel and Salha, 2005).
Gender closed brands are linked to an exclusive masculine/feminine archetype: virile and powerful man, seductive and sensual woman. Gender open brands are linked to more mixed archetypes.
Set of six bipolar scales (masculine/feminine, large/small, common/luxurious, hard/soft, rough/smooth) used by Alreck et al. (1982), and later by Jung and Lee (2006).

Agreement with the following statements on a Likert scale: ‘A business which uses this commercial is most trying to attract female consumers’ and ‘A business which uses this commercial is most trying to attract male consumers’.
Set of five bipolar scales suggested by Till and Priluck (2001), and similar to those used by Alreck et al. (1982), contrasting for example masculine/feminine, hard/soft or strong/weak traits.

For example, the authors suggest that whisky is a masculine product and margaritas are feminine: a whisky brand called Aizo will be more favorably assessed/remembered than one called Aiza, while a margarita called Aiza will be more favorably assessed/remembered than one called Aizo.

These studies with a unidimensional conceptualization of gender do not measure gender factors, but rather directly measure masculinity/femininity using the scales indicated: we cannot therefore indicate the gender factor measured in our table.
In 2006, women in France spent an average of 31 minutes each day performing this task, compared to 3 minutes in the case of men (see www.insee.fr/fr/ffc/docs_ffc/donsoc06d.pdf).
Founder and former CEO of The Body Shop.

Like the schema used by Martinot, we used three cubes, although with no intended order or hierarchy between each one. Furthermore, there may be correlative links between certain gender factors, for example gender attitudes and gender behavior (respectively measured using the AWS and MFRQ scales; see Sherman and Spence, 1997).

Take for example the following items from the AWS scale, with which subjects are asked to indicate their level of agreement: ‘The intellectual leadership of a community should be largely in the hands of men’, ‘Women should assume their rightful place in business and all the professions along with men’, ‘In general, the father should have greater authority than the mother in the bringing up of the children’.
French versions of the BSRI have been developed (Alain, 1987; Gana, 1995).
